title: Hutson case hears claims of ASIC interrogation fix
text:
In 2015, Mr Elias’ private company, West Bridge, acquired $8.5 million worth of shares in childcare giant Affinity Education. At the same time, G8 Education wanted to take over Affinity.

The prosecution case alleges Ms Hutson had arranged the financing for Mr Elias’ company to buy the Affinity shares.

The Takeovers Panel initially looked at dealings involving Mr Elias and Ms Hutson in September 2015 and ASIC again was interested in February 2016.

Mr Elias was questioned under the watchdog’s all-powerful Section 19 examination in late February. But the court heard Mr Elias had a dinner with Ms Hutson the night before the questioning, at which she allegedly asked Mr Elias to give a version of events to ASIC.

Notes from an ASIC officer’s discussions with Mr Elias the following month were aired in court, stating: “6pm, night before examination, wants me to lie to ASIC.”

Mr Elias said he believed that would have referred to the meeting.

However, Ms Hutson’s lawyer, Neil Clelland, asked why the businessman had not mentioned this claim to ASIC during the February examination.

“I can't remember,” he said on Friday.

Advertisement

Elias 'not malleable'

Mr Elias this week in court has maintained he gave a true account of matters to ASIC.

A company partly owned by Mr Elias' Print Mail had also borrowed funds from Ms Hutson’s merchant bank Wellington Capital, and this was among issues also discussed at the dinner, the court heard.

Mr Elias maintained he had signed false documents presented by Ms Hutson at another occasion as an “accommodation” to her and because he wanted to avoid “confrontation”.

That included documents the prosecution claimed had been handed over at Brisbane’s Stamford Plaza in April 2016 to help support a cover story for separate allegations involving Ms Hutson’s purported purchase of ANZ shares funded by G8.

“Why ... sign documents in those circumstances, you being the law-abiding person who’s always acted with propriety?” Mr Clelland asked.

Mr Elias said he had taken a “view very simply that this was an accommodation to her”, and West Bridge had made an $800,000 profit from the childcare shares.

It was among a series of times he told court he had acted in certain ways on Ms Hutson’s request.

Mr Elias rejected a characterisation of himself as a malleable person but agreed it was possible he simply acquiesced.

The hearing continues.
description: Merchant banker and former childcare executive Jenny Hutson is vigorously defending allegations in a court hearing.
